addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable my very singular Lord,
e L. Burghley Lord highe Treasurer of England.

31 Au
g
1591. M
r
Bodley fr
o
Haghe
Cortekens Confession

page.lettertext:
fol.353r
May it please yo
r
good L. I send yo
w
heere
the copie of Cortekens Confession, but w
t
out
e
Interrogatories, as they say they were sent from
the
states of Zeland
, albeit I am persuaded,
they will not willingly lette me see them. And
as I am informed, they have examined him
againe upon newe Interrogatories: to what
effect I knowe not, nor yet w
at
answear he hath
made. For they deale in these maters very ja-
lously w
t
me, and more, I see, I shall not knowe,
then I must of necessitie, and is likely other-
wise to be signified unto me. Of that
w
ch
concerned
e mater of peace, there is nothing
yet imparted to
e body of this
Councel:
but
every man a part is made acquainted w
t
it:
w
ch
they doe, as I suppose, lest
e bruite of suche
a motion, when
e vulgar people doe not rightly
understand it, should occasion further trouble,
then they shall after be able, to appeare when
they would.
S
r
Edward Norreis
hath
written hither to
e Councel, requesting for Cor-
teken to have him released, alleaging that
he had imploied him about her
Ma
ties
affaires:
and in case they would retene him, as a law-
full prisoner, he should be forced for his ran-
some to write unto her Hig
nes
. But they answea-
red nothing to his letter. What hath
passed in conference between me and
Vanderwerke
I have certified in my last, w
ch
is all
e occasion
I have had, to speake of that mater to any of
them all, nor till I heare from yo
r
L. I know
not further what to say, to colour that Treaty be-
tween
e Governo
r
and Corteken, as touching a
peace. There are certaine pointes
fol.353v
confessed, w
ch
verifie those abuses, wherew
t
the
Governo
r
is charged, in
e maters of contributi
o
,
w
ch
I see them heere inclined to send unto her
Ma
tie
w
t
all their other informations, thereby to
justifie whatsoever they have written heeretofore.
But what course in conclusion will be taken
by them, I can not yet conjecture. For in
their publicke assembly it was never yet pro-
posed to be finally resolved, and I finde them
diversly affected in their privat communica-
tions: some of them urging to send for him hither,
and to proceede against his dealinges by order
of justice: others requiring
at some should be
deputed to goe to
Ostend,
and there examine
and determine, as shall be thought expedient.
There are also some
at thinke it best, that all
their informations should be sent unto her Ma
tie
w
t
earnest request to revoke him from thens:
whereto there are divers
at would willingly
condescend: but they would have
e Garrison
heereafter to be kept by a Governor and souldiers
of
e contrey. But to all these opinions there
are among themselves,
at doe make oppositions.
For first they imagine
at he will not come, all-
though he were sent for: and to send unto him
thither, they thinke it not convenient, where ma-
ters are so evident, nor for
e Councels reputa-
tion. To pray her Hig
nes
to revoke him, they
hold it prejudicial to
e liberties of
e contrey,
considering it is a mater in their disposition.
That w
ch
is lest gainsaid, is
e changing of the
Garrison: w
ch
yet they are in doubt will not
greatly please her Ma
tie
to whose good liking,
fol.354r
to say truly, they are willinger then they have
bin, to conforme their proceedinges. These thinges
are but privatly thus debated, and nothing yet
sette downe by way of resolution. Howbeit I
attend every houre their meeting upon it, whiche
I thinke will be general, aswel of
e states as
of
e Councel.
Wherew
t
I take my humble leave.
From
e Hage. Au
g
30
31 1591.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
